Award.AwardTitle: Kinetic Approaches for Multi-Scale Problems in Quantum Chemistry and Seismology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project concerns an interdisciplinary topic that is of general interest to both computational mathematicians and scientists from other areas. This project will lead to quantitative understanding of the optical properties of crystals and in imaging Earth rock structures clearly, simply, and quickly. More importantly, these new methods will provide important advances in computational mathematics, leading to practical benefit in the fields of materials science and seismology.

This work is motivated by recent work on Frozen Gaussian Approximation (FGA) and its unique interpretation of high-frequency waves that suggests many new numerical techniques embedded. State-of-the-art numerical methods will be developed and used in various applications. The work will have impact in a wide range of problems of significant interest in physical sciences and industry. Specifically, the project investigates the following topics: 1. To theoretically study the FGA method in more depth. This includes analyzing the asymptotic accuracy of FGA, and integrating it with the Tailored Finite Point/Cell Method (TFPM/TFCM). 2. To study the dynamics of electrons in crystals by computing the Schr√∂dinger equation with a lattice potential in both the Lagrangian and Eulerian approaches. 3. To compute seismic wave propagation in heterogeneous or non-lateral media based on FGA and its combination with TFPM/TFCM. 4. To survey the practical performance of developed numerical methods on, e.g., tsunami and earthquake models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The proposed research projects supported by the grant are on an interdisciplinary topic that is of general interest to both applied mathematicians and scientists from other areas. The dynamics of electrons in crystals are one of the main concerns in quantum chemistry, and the acoustic wave propagation attracts a great amount of attention from geophysicists. The grant has resulted in two accepted papers and sixteen peer-reviewed journal publications, including Geophysical Journal International, a prestigious journal in geophysics. A series of research goals have been achieved by collaborations with graduate students at University of California, Santa Barbara, and both domestic and international scientists:

1. Study the crust structure of the 1992 Lander earthquake area, and the results (added image) show satisfactory recovery rates at 21.0 km and clearly reveal the low-velocity anomalies along the San Andreas fault (SAF), San Jacinto fault (SJF) and Elsinore fault (EF), which were not reported by previous studies due to poor resolutionin the lower crust;

2. Develop frozen Gaussian approximation (FGA) for three-dimensional (3D) seismic tomography;

3. Derive and analyze the FGA method for the Schrödinger equation with a lattice potential, and develop an efficient gauge-invariant numerical algorithm for computing the Schrödinger equation with a lattice potential;

4. Design a novel earthquake location method using acoustic wave-equation-based traveltime inversion;

5. Rigorously derive the semiclassical and diffusion limit of the Schrödinger-Poisson-Landau-Lifshitz-Gilbert system spin for dynamics in multilayered ferromagnetic media;

6. Design an FGA-based multi-level particle swarm optimization for seismic inversion;

7. Derive a mean-field model for spin dynamics in multilayered ferromagnetic media, and apply it to current-driven domain wall motion in ferromagnetic materials;

8. Develop FGA-based two-level methods for multi-frequency time dependent Schrödinger equation;

9. Develop FGA-based domain decomposition methods for the linear Schrödinger equation beyond the semi-classical regime;

10. Derive an augmented Keller-Segal model for E. coli chemotaxis in fast-varying environments;

11. Design gradient recovery methods for high frequency wave propagation, elliptic interface problems and eigenvalue problems. 

The developed models and methods provide a pathway to the development of semiclassical approaches for computational seismology, which will lead to a long-term research direction extending these methods to solving new problems and making these methods available to investigators with limited computational resources.  

Under the support of the grant, a Hispanic graduate student (Ricardo Delgadillo) earned his Ph.D., and went to Michigan State University as a postdoc. He was the first of his family to graduate college and first got a Ph.D.. The grant also supports two graduate students of mathematics, James Hateley and Lan Liu (female), and three postdoctoral researchers Dr. Lihui Chai, Dr. Hailong Guo (will be a tenure-track assistant professor at Melbourne University, Australia in July 2018) and Dr. Jingrun Chen (now a tenure-track assistant professor at Soochow University, China, and awarded in the Thousand Talents Plan Young Professionals Program 2016). The PI gave several invited talks at national and international conferences and universities where he reported on the progress of the projects of this grant.
